title: Usk Valley Walk Route

images.title: Philip Halling / The Usk Valley Walk
images.caption: The Usk Valley Walk to the north of the town of Usk, the river is just the other side of the trees on the left. The route runs for about 48 miles so needs between 3 and 5 days for completion.

images.title: Philip Halling / Stile on the Usk Valley Walk
images.caption: Stile on the Usk Valley Walk. View towards the Brecon Beacons from the Usk Valley Walk above Aber village.

images.title: Philip Halling / The Usk Valley Walk
images.caption: For part of the route between Llantrisant and Llanllywell the Usk Valley Walk follows the east bank of the river.

images.title: Philip Halling / Ruin beside the Usk Valley Walk
images.caption: The ruin of a stone building beside the Usk Valley Walk near Pencelli.

images.title: Caerleon and the River Usk by Ian Capper, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Caerleon and the River Usk. A view over the valley and the town which marks the start point for the walk. There are a number of ancient Roman sites to explore in the town. The town is also not far from the rivermouth at Uskmouth which lies just to the south of Newport.

images.title: Usk Bridge, Abergavenny by Gareth James, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Usk Bridge, Abergavenny

images.title: Talybont Reservoir by don cload, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Talybont Reservoir. The trail passes just north of this large reservoir near Llangynidr. There are wonderful views of the Brecon Beacons and the Black Mountains around here.

images.title: Brecon: River Usk by Keith Salvesen, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The river at Brecon at the end of the walk. Brecon is the third-largest town in Powys, after Newtown and Ystradgynlais. It lies north of the Brecon Beacons mountain range, but is just within the Brecon Beacons National Park.

description: This super waterside walk follows the River Usk, the Monmouthshire and Brecon Canal and the Brecon and Newport Canal from Caerleon to Brecon. The walk passes through Abergavenny and Usk and is enclosed by beautiful hills for the whole of its length. There are also splendid views of the Brecon Beacon mountains, particularly towards the end of the walk. The route is relativley flat as much of it takes place alongside the river or the canals, so there are only a few notable climbs. The walk is waymarked using a white symbol of an otter's head, an animal you may well see on the river.
